factoid: The Rostóvs returned to Moscow in the autumn.
Denísov returned to Moscow early in the winter and stayed with the Rostóvs.
The first half of the winter of 1806 was one of the happiest and merriest times for Nicholas Rostóv and his family.
Nicholas Rostóv brought many young men to his parents' house.
Véra was a handsome girl of twenty.
Sónya was a girl of sixteen with all the charm of an opening flower.
Natásha was half grown up and half child, sometimes childishly amusing and sometimes girlishly enchanting.
An amorous atmosphere prevailed in the Rostóvs' house at that time, characteristic of homes with very young and very charming girls.
Every young man who came to the Rostóvs' house experienced an amorous feeling.
The young men shared a readiness to fall in love and an expectation of happiness with the young folk of the Rostóvs' household.
Dólokhov was one of the first young men introduced by Nicholas Rostóv, and everyone in the house liked him except Natásha.
Natásha almost quarreled with her brother about Dólokhov.
Natásha insisted that Dólokhov was a bad man, that Pierre was right in the duel with Bezúkhov and Dólokhov was wrong, and that he was disagreeable and unnatural.
Natásha said that she could not understand Dólokhov, calling him wicked and heartless, but she liked Denísov even though he was a rake.
Nicholas said that Denísov was quite different and that Dólokhov had a soul and a heart.
Nicholas said that he was uncomfortable with Dólokhov and that Dólokhov had fallen in love with Sónya.
Nicholas was certain that Dólokhov had fallen in love with Sónya.
Natásha’s prediction that Dólokhov had fallen in love with Sónya proved true.
Dólokhov, who did not usually care for the society of ladies, began to come often to the house because of Sónya.
Sónya knew that Dólokhov loved her and blushed scarlet every time he appeared.
Dólokhov often dined at the Rostóvs' house, never missed a performance at which the family was present, and went to Iogel's balls for young people that the Rostóvs always attended.
Dólokhov was pointedly attentive to Sónya and looked at her in a way that made her blush, and also made the old countess and Natásha blush.
It was evident that Dólokhov was under the irresistible influence of the dark, graceful girl who loved another.
Nicholas Rostóv noticed something new in Dólokhov's relations with Sónya but did not explain what they were.
Nicholas Rostóv thought that Sónya and Natásha were always in love with someone, and he was less at ease with Sónya and Dólokhov than before, and he was less frequently at home.
In the autumn of 1806, everybody began talking about the war with Napoleon with greater warmth than the year before.
Orders were given to raise recruits: ten men in every thousand for the regular army and nine men in every thousand for the militia.
Bonaparte was anathematized everywhere and in Moscow nothing but the coming war was talked about.
The Rostóv family was interested in the war preparations because Nicholas would not stay in Moscow and awaited the end of Denísov's furlough after Christmas to return with him to their regiment.
Nicholas's approaching departure gave zest to his pleasures.
Nicholas spent most of his time away from home at dinners, parties, and balls.
